DOC.HEAD: White House Defends Secret Missions
Eds: Top 8 grafs with new defense of mission; picks up at pvs 6th graf, it was, and edits Fitzwater reference in pvs 11th graf, However, White
DOC.TEXT: The White House today defended President Bush's secret dealings with China, insisting he has been forthright with the American people but saying he feels free to send emissaries on unpublicized missions. The statement from White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater came amid criticism from a congressional leader that Bush ``misled the American people'' by sending high-level officials to Beijing barely a month after the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. The secret mission in July, kept hidden from the public and Congress until Monday, was carried out by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. The two officials visited Beijing on Bush's orders even as the United States was saying that high-level U.S. exchanges had been cut in protest of the crushing of the pro-democracy movement. ``We've been forthright,'' Fitzwater said today. ``The forthrightness is in saying we are going to have these kinds of contacts. ``We have and will have (such trips) and they will be secret, and it is not misleading to tell you about everything he's doing. The president's up there in the Oval Office doing things all day long that you don't know and won't know about, and that's not misleading,'' the spokesman said. He refused to say whether there have been any other high-level contacts with China that have been kept secret. Speaking generally about Bush's foreign policy, Fitzwater said, ``There have been trips you don't know about and there will be more.'' It was Scowcroft and Eagleburger who also quietly traveled to China this month expressing hopes to ``bring new impetus and vigor'' in Sino-American relations. In Beijing today, China's Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying the government had received Scowcroft last July at the Unites States' request. ``Such high-level contacts between China and the United States are useful and conducive to enhancing the mutual understanding,'' the statement from Beijing said. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said in a statement he was ``astonished'' to learn of the July meeting, saying the trips to Beijing ``make a mockery of our profession of concern for human rights and the stated ideals of our democratic system of government.'' Mitchell called on the Bush administration to disclose all U.S. contacts with the Chinese government. However, Fitzwater said Monday that he could not rule out the possibility that Scowcroft and Eagleburger, or other top officials, had made other, still-secret trips to China. The Dec. 8 visit was announced after the two officials arrived in Beijing. The July visit was acknowledged only after it was reported by the Cable News Network, and the White House refused to provide any details, even the date of the trip. Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., chairman of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on trade, said Bush ``misled the American people and the Congress.'' ``How does the White House square that (earlier trip) with their statements at the time that high-level contacts with the Chinese were cut off?'' Gejdenson said. ``The sad reality is that the president confuses his personal relationship with the Chinese leaders with what is good national policy.'' Fitzwater said Bush felt it was essential to hold quiet diplomatic discussions with China outside ``the public glare'' regarding its crackdown. ``The president has had years of experience with China and he knows that face-to-face declarations are important to them, and felt it was important that they knew privately and from someone on his immediate staff just how strongly the United States felt about this,'' Fitzwater said. A White House statement said the July mission was undertaken to underscore U.S. ``shock and concern about the violence in Tiananmen Square and to impress upon the Chinese government the seriousness with which this incident was viewed in the United States.'' Even before the July trip to Beijing was disclosed, Bush was defending his China policies, insisting that the United States should not isolate a country with a population of more than a billion people. Bush refused to say whether China's hardline leaders offered any concessions in exchange for his gesture of taking the first step to repair relations. ``I'm not going to discuss what I did or didn't get,'' the president said. ``You see, I still believe that sometimes to affect change, you talk in confidence to people,'' Bush said, who has been accused by Democrats of ``kowtowing'' to China. ``And I notice now,'' Bush said, ``that some of the critics who were so opposed (and) using this fantastically, diabolically anti-me language, they come up now in saying, `Well, if you get a, b and c, then it will be all right, or then we'll understand. Let them just stay tuned.'' Bush also said he does not know when Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi will be able to leave the U.S. embassy in Beijing, where he has taken refuge since the crackdown. Quoting Scowcroft, Fitzwater denied there were any negotiations with China about an acceptable country where Fang might go.
